items.description:
Il sostegno economico alle famiglie si rafforza con l’introduzione del bonus che si aggiunge a un articolato sistema
L'articolo Fino a 7000 euro per l
items.body: Sostenibilità Fino a 7000 euro per le famgilie, il nuovo bonus da non perdere: richiederli è semplicissimo    Roberto Arciola    Agosto 13, 2025     Bonus figli da 1200 euro e integrazione con altri aiuti(www.greenstyle.it) Il sostegno economico alle famiglie si rafforza con l’introduzione del bonus che si aggiunge a un articolato sistema di aiuti già esistente.In un contesto segnato da crescenti difficoltà economiche e da una bassa natalità, il governo italiano ha intensificato l’attenzione verso la genitorialità, mettendo in campo risorse che mirano a sostenere concretamente le famiglie con figli.Il bonus figli da 1200 euro rappresenta un sostegno economico immediato, erogato in un’unica soluzione, destinato a integrare le altre forme di assistenza già previste dal sistema italiano. Si tratta di un intervento pensato per alleggerire il carico finanziario delle famiglie, facilitando la gestione delle spese legate all’educazione e al benessere dei bambini.Questa misura coesiste con il Bonus nuovi nati o Carta nuovi nati, che consiste in un contributo di 1000 euro erogato sotto forma di carta prepagata destinata all’acquisto di beni e servizi essenziali per i neonati. Non si tratta quindi di denaro liquido, ma di un supporto mirato all’acquisto di prodotti specifici, consolidando così la rete di aiuti per le famiglie con bambini appena nati o adottati.Parallelamente, l’Assegno unico universale fornisce un aiuto economico mensile che varia in base all’ISEE familiare e al numero di figli a carico. Per i nuclei con ISEE fino a circa 17.000 euro, l’assegno può raggiungere i 199 euro mensili per ogni figlio minore, offrendo un sostegno costante e duraturo nell’arco dell’anno.Un altro contributo rilevante è il Bonus asilo nido, che può arrivare fino a 3.600 euro annui per ogni bambino iscritto a strutture pubbliche o private autorizzate. Questo aiuto è fondamentale per ridurre i costi di custodia e favorire la conciliazione tra lavoro e famiglia.Sommando tutti questi incentivi – dal bonus una tantum da 1200 euro all’assegno mensile, passando per il contributo asilo nido – una famiglia può arrivare a ricevere fino a 7000 euro nel primo anno di vita del proprio figlio, con possibilità di incrementi legati a condizioni particolari, come la presenza di più figli o altre situazioni specifiche.Procedura semplificata e accesso ai bonusL’accesso ai vari bonus è stato reso più agevole grazie all’azione dell’INPS, che ha sviluppato piattaforme digitali dedicate per la presentazione delle domande e per accelerare l’erogazione dei fondi. I requisiti, le modalità di richiesta e le scadenze sono consultabili in maniera chiara sui siti istituzionali o presso gli sportelli informativi distribuiti sul territorio nazionale.In particolare, il bonus asilo nido prevede un contributo calcolato in base all’ISEE minorenni e può essere richiesto fino al 31 dicembre dell’anno di riferimento. L’importo massimo, per i bambini nati dal 1° gennaio 2024, arriva a 3.600 euro annui per famiglie con ISEE minorenni fino a 40.000 euro, mentre scende a 1.500 euro per nuclei con ISEE superiore o non presente. Il contributo viene erogato mensilmente, fino a un massimo di undici rate annuali, e non è cumulabile con le detrazioni fiscali per la frequenza agli asili nido.Per le famiglie che hanno bambini con gravi patologie croniche e che non possono frequentare l’asilo nido, è previsto un contributo specifico per il supporto presso la propria abitazione, erogato in un’unica soluzione. Impegno dello Stato e prospettive per la natalità(www.greenstyle.it)L’insieme di queste misure testimonia la volontà dello Stato italiano di intervenire con strumenti efficaci e tempestivi per sostenere la genitorialità e contrastare il calo demografico che da anni caratterizza il paese. Offrire un aiuto concreto alle famiglie, soprattutto a quelle più fragili o numerose, è diventato un obiettivo prioritario per le politiche sociali.Questi incentivi, uniti a un sistema di assistenza sempre più integrato, rappresentano un passo importante per creare un ambiente favorevole alla crescita dei bambini e per accompagnare i genitori nelle prime fasi della loro esperienza di cura.Le famiglie italiane possono quindi guardare al futuro con maggiore fiducia sapendo di poter contare su un sostegno finanziario complessivo che, nel primo anno di vita del bambino, può superare i 7000 euro grazie alla combinazione di bonus e assegni.L’attenzione del governo rimane alta anche sul fronte della semplificazione burocratica, essenziale per garantire che gli aiuti arrivino rapidamente a chi ne ha bisogno, contribuendo a migliorare la qualità della vita delle famiglie italiane e a stimolare una ripresa della natalità nel paese. items.title: Just how bad will climate change get? The only way to know is to fund basic research
items.body:
WORLD VIEW
                13 August 2025

Just how bad will climate change get? The only way to know is to fund basic research

Predictions of climate change are uncertain. That’s why we need to keep finding out how our atmosphere works.
                
            
        
        
            
                By

Tim Palmer0

Tim Palmer
                
                
                    
                        
                            Tim Palmer is an emeritus professor of climate science at the University of Oxford, UK, and author of The Primacy of Doubt (2022).
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        
                            View author publications
                            
                                
                                    Search author on:
                                    PubMed
                                     Google Scholar

Twitter
            
        
    
    
        
            Facebook
            
        
    
    
        
            Email

How seriously should people be taking climate change? United Nations secretary-general António Gutteres considers it an existential threat. Yet, US President Donald Trump has decreed it a hoax. On 29 July, a US Department of Energy (DOE) report by a group of contrarian climate scientists concluded that “CO2-induced warming might be less damaging economically than commonly believed, and excessively aggressive mitigation policies could prove more detrimental than beneficial” (see go.nature.com/4amktth).What does the science say: hoax, lukewarm inconvenience or catastrophe? According to the best-available evidence, none of the above is right.There is much in the DOE report to be critical of (see Nature https://doi.org/pz8h; 2025). However, its authors are correct in one respect: the most important uncertainty in our ability to predict how much global temperatures will increase as carbon emissions continue is related to how cloud coverage will change over time.How AI is improving climate forecastsLow-level clouds reflect sunlight back to space, whereas high-level ones trap heat emitted from Earth’s surface. Most climate models predict that, overall, clouds will amplify the effects of humanity’s greenhouse-gas emissions through a decrease in cover by low-level clouds and an increase for high-level ones. If so, global temperatures could rise by 4 °C or more — a catastrophe because of the amount of sea-level rise and the increasing occurrence of deadly heatwaves.But the opposite scenario cannot be ruled out fully. Increased low-level cloud cover would reflect extra sunlight and help to offset the warming effect of climate change — a relatively lukewarm outcome.One reason for this uncertainty is that, in the models, cloud-forming processes are represented by simplified formulae. Another is related to how cloud formation differs around the globe because of air-temperature and humidity variations linked to wind patterns. Climate models make systematic errors when predicting such patterns. This is unsurprising: climate is a non-linear system in which processes on many scales interact in complex ways. Thus, simulating clouds is a formidable challenge.So far, there is no clear evidence from observations that clouds are responding to humanity’s emissions by increasing or decreasing coverage systematically. There are some data that low-level cloud cover was reduced in the Northern Hemisphere and tropics in 2023, contributing to the exceptionally high global temperatures that year1. But researchers don’t yet have enough data to know whether this was a one-off or part of an emerging change in cloud characteristics.Why the green-technology race might not save the planet

Mare e laghi italiani non godono di ottima salute

12 Agosto 2025

Legambiente

12 Agosto 2025

Comunicati stampa

laghi , Mare

Il bilancio finale di Legambiente con Goletta Verde e Goletta dei Laghi 2025. Inquinamento, maladepurazione e crisi climatica i nemici principali.

“Urgente approvare un piano nazionale per la tutela delle acque costiere e interne, prevedere più risorse per ammodernare gli impianti di depurazione, più controlli da parte di Regioni, Arpa e Comuni sui punti critici e una migliore gestione delle acque interne. Stanziare con urgenza le risorse economiche per infrastrutturare i porti di Taranto e Augusta per la logistica dell’eolico offshore”
Inquinamento, maladepurazione e crisi climatica minacciano sempre più mare e laghi italiani. Il bilancio finale delle campagne estive di Legambiente – Goletta Verde e Goletta dei Laghi 2025 – restituisce una chiara fotografia di sintesi. Nell’estate 2025 su 388 campionamenti effettuati nelle acque costiere e lacustri in 19 regioni dagli oltre 200 volontari e volontarie di regionali e circoli di Legambiente, il 34% è risultato oltre i limiti di legge, ossia 1 campione su 3.  In particolare, il 35% dei punti campionati con Goletta Verde è risultato inquinato o fortemente inquinamento con una media di un punto ogni 80 km, per i laghi il 30% è risultato oltre i limiti di legge.  
Anche quest’anno foci dei fiumi, canali e corsi d’acqua che sfociano a mare o nel lago si confermano punti critici: il 54% dei punti critici analizzati (101 su 188) è risultato inquinato o fortemente inquinato. Situazione migliore per i campioni prelevati direttamente in mare o nelle acque del lago, ossia in aree lontane da foci o scarichi, dove solo il 15% dei punti campionati è risultato oltre i limiti di legge (30 su 200). Sulla questione foci a mare, Legambiente denuncia che il 56% di quelle monitorate da Goletta Verde, non controllate dalle autorità competenti e di conseguenza non balneabili, risultano avere in prossimità una spiaggia libera. Un dato preoccupante se si pensa che oltre 220km di costa sabbiosa ad oggi non sono monitorati dalle autorità competenti (sui 3.346 km di costa bassa), ovvero il 6,6%, e alle poche spiagge libere rimaste nella Penisola, soprattutto in alcune regioni.  
Guarda la mappa dei monitoraggi
Crisi climatica e rifiuti
Al problema dell’inquinamento e dei pochi controlli, si affianca quello della crisi climatica e dei rifiuti. Al grido “Non è caldo, è crisi climatica”, Legambiente – rielaborando i dati forniti dalle immagini satellitari di Copernicus – ha calcolato che a giugno e luglio la temperatura media delle acque superficiali del Mediterraneo è stata di 25,4°C, la più calda dal 2016 ad oggi, collocandosi al primo posto nell’ultimo decennio, e superando i precedenti record del 2022 (media 25,2°C) e quello del 2024 (25,1°C) e i valori degli anni fino al 2021 che erano intorno ai 24,5°C. Un aumento sensibile di circa mezzo grado centigrado che mette a repentaglio la biodiversità marina e che amplifica gli eventi metereologici più estremi e persistenti per via di una sempre maggiore evaporazione delle acque marine e dell’energia termica accumulata, in particolare nei mesi estivi, che viene rilasciata successivamente con eventi meteo estremi. E poi c’è il grande tema dei rifiuti in spiaggia e a mare, affrontato da Goletta Verde quest’anno insieme a Puliamo il Mondo, campagna storica di volontariato ambientale di Legambiente, con un’attività di pulizia dei fondali e della costa in Calabria, sul lungomare di Tropea. Esposta durante la conferenza stampa la teca con alcuni dei rifiuti raccolti durante l’attività di pulizia nella tappa calabrese.  
Il bilancio è stato presentato questa mattina a Roma per fare un punto sui risultati e sul viaggio delle due campagne estive di Legambiente – la 39esima edizione di Goletta Verde, con la partnership principale di ANEV, CONOU, Novamont (Versalis – ENI), Renexia e partner tecnico Biorepack,  e la 20esima edizione di Goletta dei Laghi, con la partnership principale di CONOU, Novamont e partner tecnico Biorepack. Alla conferenza stampa, moderata da Francesca Cugnata, coordinatrice campagne Legambiente, hanno partecipato: Stefano Ciafani, presidente nazionale di Legambiente, Andrea Minutolo, responsabile scientifico di Legambiente, Katiuscia Eroe, responsabile energia di Legambiente, Simone Togni, presidente di ANEV, Riccardo Piunti, presidente del CONOU, Andrea Porchera, responsabile relazioni istituzionali e comunicazione di Renexia.

Il nostro appello
Di fronte al bilancio emerso da Goletta Verde e dei Laghi, Legambiente torna a ribadire l’urgenza di approvare un piano nazionale per la tutela delle acque costiere e interne che abbia al centro una governance integrata su più livelli prevedendo piani di adattamento ai cambiamenti climatici; più risorse economiche da destinare al servizio di depurazione per ammodernare gli impianti rispondendo ai più stringenti parametri per il trattamento e riuso delle acque reflue; più controlli da parte di Regioni, Arpa e Comuni sui punti critici e una migliore gestione delle acque interne. Sul fronte rinnovabili, è fondamentale spingere sulle fonti pulite a partire dall’eolico offshore, visto il grande potenziale e il fatto che questa tecnologia possa convivere con la fauna marina, come dimostrato dallo studio “Energia Rinnovabile e Conservazione Marina. Il case study dell’impianto Beleolico di Taranto” presentato da Goletta Verde insieme a Jonian Dolphin Conservation nella tappa di Taranto. Per Legambiente l’Italia deve accelerare su questa fonte rinnovabile, dando tempi certi, iter autorizzativi più snelli e coinvolgendo i territori nel dibattito pubblico.  Per prevenire l’inquinamento delle nostre acque occorre intervenire sulle cause all’origine, ossia sugli scarichi non depurati e sugli sversamenti illegali nelle acque superficiali. La maladepurazione resta il grande tallone d’Achille del nostro Paese che ha già pagato sanzioni pecuniarie per circa 210 milioni di euro, a cui vanno aggiunti i ritardi ormai cronici rispetto al trattamento delle acque reflue. Inoltre, con la recente approvazione della revisione normativa della Direttiva Acque Reflue, gli impianti del paese dovranno adattarsi ai nuovi requisiti, una spesa che è stata stimata tra i 645 milioni e 1,5 miliardi di euro solo per gli impianti di maggiori dimensioni.  
“Al Governo – commenta Stefano Ciafani, presidente nazionale di Legambiente – chiediamo di definire e approvare al più presto un piano nazionale per la tutela di mare e laghi, investendo su innovazione e sostenibilità per ammodernare i sistemi di depurazione e per diffondere il riuso in agricoltura delle acque depurate. Sullo sviluppo delle rinnovabili in mare, dopo l’approvazione del decreto porti, è urgente stanziare le risorse economiche necessarie per infrastrutturare i due hub cantieristici di Taranto e di Augusta, che potranno garantire anche nuova occupazione green a due aree portuali che hanno sempre avuto a che fare con la logistica delle fonti fossili”. 
Focus Maladepurazione

Attualmente in Italia il 4,4% del carico inquinante generato da più di 78 milioni di abitanti equivalenti o non è collegato (0,7%) oppure è trattato con sistemi individuali (per il 3,7%). Parliamo di un carico di quasi 3 milioni e mezzo di abitanti equivalenti che non viene trattato in modo sicuro (con sistemi di trattamento secondario o superiore). A questi si aggiungano i carichi che confluiscono agli impianti di trattamento che attualmente si trovano in procedura di infrazione rispetto ai requisiti della Direttiva Acque Reflue che, dagli aggiornamenti facilmente reperibili sul sito del MASE, ammontano a 855 agglomerati, relativi a più di 26 milioni e 800 mila abitanti equivalenti che corrispondono al 34% del carico complessivo generato in Italia. Non dimentichiamo, sottolinea Legambiente, che sull’Italia pesano 4 procedure di infrazione per la mancata conformità alla Direttiva Acque Reflue (91/271/CEE). L’ultima (2017/2181) è ancora in fase di istruttoria, le prime tre sono già sfociate in sentenza di condanna e in particolare la prima, risalente al 2004, è giunta fino alla sanzione pecuniaria. Ad oggi, secondo la Corte dei conti, sono stati versati oltre 210 milioni di euro solo per la multa derivante dalla prima procedura di infrazione, mentre la sentenza della Corte di Giustizia per la seconda infrazione è arrivata a marzo 2025 e la multa ammonta a 10 milioni di euro più una penalità di oltre 13 milioni e mezzo ogni 6 mesi di ritardo per la messa a norma degli impianti.  
FOCUS MARE E LAGHI GOLETTE 2025  
Mare e foci
Su 263 punti campionati lungo gli oltre 7.500 km di costa italiana, l’8% è stato giudicato inquinato e il 27% fortemente inquinato. I problemi principali si sono avuti alle foci dei fiumi, dove il 58% delle analisi (69 su 119) ha avuto esito negativo risultando inquinato (15) o fortemente inquinato (54). Balza agli occhi come il 71% delle foci monitorate nella campagna Goletta Verde (85 su 119) corrisponda a tratti di costa non campionati dalle autorità competenti e di queste ben 47 siano risultate oltre i limiti di legge.  
“Un’anomalia – spiega Andrea Minutolo, responsabile scientifico di Legambiente – che viene spesso giustificata dalle autorità competenti con il fatto che le foci dei fiumi non sono balneabili e che si dia per scontato che siano inquinate. È questa la reale differenza tra i campionamenti eseguiti dalle autorità competenti per stabilire la balneazione di un tratto di costa, e quelle eseguite da Legambiente che hanno come obiettivo individuare le criticità dovute ad una scarsa o assente depurazione che minaccia la qualità del mare. Ma dietro questa mancanza di campionamenti alle foci dei fiumi, si cela anche un’altra criticità, il fatto che spesso si trovino spiagge libere oggi sempre più relegate a zone di serie B mentre i numerosi cittadini che vogliono fruirne meriterebbero di trovarle almeno in luoghi monitorati e balneabili”.   
Laghi
44 i laghi campionati da Goletta dei Laghi in 11 regioni che hanno portato al prelievo di 125 campioni di acqua sottoposto ad analisi microbiologiche. Il 30% dei campionamenti (38 su 125) è risultato oltre i limiti di legge. Nello specifico 9 sono stati i campioni giudicati inquinati e 29 quelli fortemente inquinati. Oltre alle analisi microbiologiche, nel corso della Goletta dei Laghi 2025 sono state eseguite anche delle analisi chimico fisiche su 7 laghi (Lago della Serraia in Trentino-Alto Adige, Lago Pertusillo in Basilicata e laghi Arvo, Cecita, Ampollino, Ariamacina e del Passante in Calabria). Tutte entro i limiti le analisi condotte che hanno riguardato i valori di azoto, nitriti, nitrati, fosforo, cloruri e solfati nei laghi calabresi e che risultano tutti nei range delle classi di qualità più elevate; azoto e fosforo nel lago trentino. Inoltre, è stata posta nuovamente l’attenzione sulle microplastiche nei laghi grazie alla tappa nazionale svolta sul Lago d’Orta.

Legambiente ricorda come le analisi e i giudizi espressi dalle Golette non vanno a sostituirsi al lavoro delle autorità competenti in materia di balneazione: sono infatti diversi gli obiettivi delle campagne di Legambiente, incentrate sul tema della scarsa o assente depurazione; nella maggior parte dei casi, inoltre, anche i punti dove vengono prelevati i campioni di acqua sono differenti rispetto a quelli monitorati dalle Arpa e dalle ATS, essendo i primi anche nelle foci dei fiumi o nei tratti di mare o lago antistanti le stesse. I risultati di Legambiente non esprimono quindi una patente per la balneabilità di un tratto di costa o sponda lacustre, ma restituiscono una istantanea volta a scovare criticità legate all’inquinamento microbiologico delle acque dovuto ad una scarsa o assente depurazione.  
 
Buone notizie
Tra le buone notizie, oltre al gemellaggio Goletta Verde e Puliamo il Mondo, anche l’avvistamento di un gruppo di delfini durante la navigazione di Goletta Verde in direzione Maratea, il successo dei Tartadog, prime unità cinofile, pensate nell’ambito del progetto LIFE TURTLENEST, specializzate nella ricerca dei nidi di tartarughe marine, come ha dimostrato il cane Mira durante la tappa campana di Goletta Verde. Ed ancora la regata sui laghi lombardi e l’attività di monitoraggio condotta sul Lago d’Orta sul tema microplastiche. Anche quest’anno è stato importante il successo dei laboratori didattici a bordo di Goletta Verde con al centro i progetti Life Sea.Net, Life Turtlenest e Life Elife dedicati a biodiversità dei mari, squali, cetacei e tartarughe marine.

items.body:

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 12 August 2025

Skillful subseasonal soil moisture drought forecasts with deep learning-dynamic models
                    Kyle Lesinger 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0180-43531 nAff2 & Di Tian 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7752-947X1

Nature Communications

volume 16, Article number: 7461 (2025)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
        
        
            
                
                
                
                    
                        
                            10 Altmetric
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        Metrics details

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingHydrologyProjection and prediction

AbstractDeep neural networks that learn from climate reanalysis data have produced skillful weather forecasts within ten days. However, it is still a great challenge for dynamic models to predict soil moisture, droughts, and other extreme events with lead times beyond two weeks. Here, we combine a recursive deep learning model (namely RISE-UNet) and subseasonal forecasts from dynamic models and achieve skillful forecasts of root zone soil moisture up to four weeks in advance. Our hybrid model, combining RISE-UNet and dynamic model forecasts, outperforms reanalysis-driven RISE-UNet models, while both methods show significantly higher performance than the latest European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS) dynamic models, the postprocessed ECMWF or GEFS subseasonal forecasts by RISE-UNet, or ensemble model output statistics. The hybrid model shows skill in predicting flash droughts, which is higher than ECMWF and GEFS models in most cases, as demonstrated for major events in the United States, China, and Australia. The forecast skill of the hybrid modeling approach from weeks three to four is mainly due to the inclusion of the first two-week dynamic model forecasts and antecedent root zone soil moisture reanalysis. Our results indicate that combining deep learning with dynamic model forecasts can substantially improve the skill of subseasonal predictions beyond two weeks, particularly for root zone soil moisture and flash drought events.

                        IntroductionRoot-zone soil moisture (RZSM) is an essential climate variable which influences water and energy cycles and regulates thermodynamic exchanges between land and atmosphere, thereby influencing regional weather and climate conditions1,2,3. Excessive RZSM drying, also known as drought, have great socio-environmental impacts related to food security, forestry, human health, environmental sustainability, or biological community structure4,5,6,7. RZSM influences both land surface and atmospheric processes through mass and energy exchanges, and its variability can be influenced by regional seasonality, internal atmospheric variability from climate oscillations, or human-induced through anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions or land cover change8,9,10. Given its vital importance for controlling land-atmospheric feedbacks, regulating water and energy processes, and determining extreme events such as droughts and heat waves, skillful RZSM forecasts at long leads are crucial for drought management, climate adaptation, mitigation, and decision making11,12,13.Previous studies have consistently identified limited subseasonal forecast skill beyond two weeks (>14 days) in current dynamic forecast systems and land surface models, including but not limited to: Noah-MP, Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF), Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC), Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS), and subseasonal-to-seasonal European Center for Medium Range Weather (S2S ECMWF)13,14,15,16,17,18,19,20. The subseasonal time scales ranges between ~14–60 days (~2–9 weeks), and low skill within models has been attributed to several factors, including unskillful precipitation forecasts, imperfect model parameterizations, initialization biases, and cumulative error growth associated with stochastic processes13,21. To increase dynamic models (DM) forecast reliability and reduce model biases, post-processing bias-correction techniques are applied to DM forecasts with respect to observations (or reanalysis), which have improved subseasonal forecast skill of temperature, precipitation, windspeed, and organized motion associated with the Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO)22,23,24,25. While bias correction can improve forecasts of mean conditions, substantial challenges remain in predicting extreme events, as bias-corrected forecasts often show limited skill beyond two weeks26.RZSM has a memory in which dry or wet anomalies, relative to the climatological mean, decay slowly for time periods between days to months and enhance land-atmosphere feedbacks through radiative and mass exchanges27,28,29. Soil moisture memory (SMM) varies across geographic regions, seasons, and soil depths, and is influenced by dynamic factors such as solar radiation, vegetation, and precipitation, as well as static factors like slope and soil texture30. While SMM can be a potential source of subseasonal predictability, previous studies have robustly identified that the prediction skill of dry extremes of RZSM is still limited beyond two weeks using either DMs, hybrid statistical-DMs, or machine learning methods13,19,26,30. This low predictability can be attributed to large errors in precipitation forecasts, which affect root zone soil moisture (RZSM) through well-known processes such as infiltration and recharge, as well as to poor representation of precipitation in computing dynamic mass and energy fluxes. To improve subseasonal RZSM predictability beyond current land surface models that rely on error-prone precipitation forecasts, novel methods are needed to overcome this limitation.Deep learning (DL) has the strength of learning complex systems by automatic extraction of spatial-temporal features31. By directly learning from historical reanalysis data, DL has achieved notable successes in ten-day medium-range weather predictions32,33, five-day extreme flood predictions34, and seasonal predictions of El Nino South Oscillation35 (ENSO), all showing improved performance compared to state-of-the-art DMs. Recent studies have also developed DL models for subseasonal predictions of atmospheric variables, while the method did not outperform state-of-the-art DMs, particularly at shorter leads (< 10 days)36. Due to SMM and improved medium-range weather prediction, DL has a great potential to skillfully predict subseasonal soil moisture and droughts beyond two weeks.Few studies to date have explored the potential of deep learning (DL) for subseasonal prediction of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) and drought. In addition, DL-based post-processing for bias correction of spatial RZSM forecasts remains largely unexplored. Here, we present a novel hybrid approach that skillfully predicts subseasonal RZSM and droughts by combining a recursive DL model (namely RISE-UNet) with state-of-the-art dynamic models (DMs). We investigate whether DL models trained on publicly available data can provide accurate long-lead predictions at subseasonal timescales and whether hybrid DL-DM models outperform reanalysis-driven DL models, DL- or statistically post-processed DMs, and the original DMs themselves. To test this, we designed a set of experiments including: hybrid DL-DM models that use inputs from DM reforecasts and reanalysis; DL- or statistically post-processed DMs that apply bias correction to DM outputs; and DL models trained on reanalysis data alone. All models are trained to predict RZSM reanalysis as the target variable. Given the global availability of training data, our approach can be implemented in other regions to support skillful subseasonal forecasting of RZSM and drought. Moreover, due to the central role of soil moisture in subseasonal-to-seasonal predictability, this framework could be extended to improve forecasts of other climate extremes, such as heavy precipitation and heatwaves, potentially benefiting water resources drought response, agriculture, urban planning, and ecosystem management.ResultsWeekly soil moisture forecast skill and feature importanceIn this study, our DL model, namely the residual inception squeeze-and-excitation (RISE) UNet + + (RISE-UNet, see Methodology), takes designed inputs and learns complex mapping functions between input variables and the RZSM forecast target (Fig. 1 and Supplementary Table S1). RISE-Unet accepts an arbitrary number of input predictors (channels) from both reanalysis at weekly lags and reforecast at forecast leads, and passes weighted convolution kernels across each channel to produce intermediate predictions, which are concatenated. Additional convolution kernels are passed along all intermediate predictions, and the image size is reduced through pooling operations, which allow different representations of the data to be computed within a more restricted field space, allowing the model to identify relevant features at different scales. These intermediate results are concatenated again, and the convolution/pooling process repeats until a minimal image size is reached (in our instance, a 48 × 96 pixel image is reduced to a 6 × 12 pixel image). Once the terminal size is reached, intermediate predictions are upscaled until the original image size is reached. For the RISE-Unet, three separate predictions are computed and the loss function applied over each one independently, with the goal of the model to reduce the aggregated loss of all three predictions.Fig. 1: The model architecture and experimental design.A Experimental design and model inputs. B RISE-UNet deep learning model architecture; C root zone soil moisture (RZSM) output for weekly leads 1–5. In the experiments, reanalysis-driven deep learning models (DL) only take reanalysis as inputs; combined DL and dynamic models (DL-DM) take both reanalysis and dynamic model forecasts; bias-corrected DM models (DM-BC_DL) only take RZSM from DM as inputs (see Supplementary Table S1 for more information). For DL-DM models, both recursive and non-recursive forecasts were made. For recursive DL-DM models, a forecast is made by recursively including the previous weeks’ RZSM prediction as an input feature. Deep learning is constructed based on a residual, inception, squeeze-and-excitation UNet + + architecture (RISE-UNet). As a comparison, DM is also bias corrected using ensemble model output statistics (DM-BC_EMOS).Full size imageWe trained the model separately for each week, lead 1–5 and verified skill results against the physically-based GLEAM reanalysis (see Methodology). For clarification, skill results are obtained for each forecast week lead made at weekly intervals across the calendar year/season for the two-year period 2018-2019. Results consistently indicate that both DL-DM and DL models show superior performance compared to DM, DM-BC_DL, and ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) (Fig. 2A, B). For week lead 3, both DL-DM and DL models achieve the highest average anomaly correlation coefficient [ACC] of ~0.60 (an increase of ~66% over DM forecasts EMOS) and the lowest average CRPS of ~0.015 (>27% improvement) across the contiguous United States (CONUS). Hybrid DL-DM and reanalysis-driven DL models consistently outperform EMOS postprocessed DM forecasts for all leads in ACC skill but only show an improvement in the CRPS at leads 3-4. DL-DM and DL models exhibit similar skill across all leads which can be the direct result of the model(s) converging on similar weights during the training process, additionally the models within scenarios are averaged across many experiments as well as across CONUS which can diminish the variability. Spatial differences between the DL experiment 24 (EX24) and the DL-DM experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (EX29_G) identify that variability in skill occurs across the entire region, albeit differences may be minimal (Fig. 2C, D). EX29_G mostly shows higher ACC than EX24 except in some of the eastern regions (Fig. 2D). EX29_G also consistently shows better CRPS than EX24 over all of CONUS, suggesting higher ensemble forecast skill (Fig. 2D). While multi-model ensemble is commonly used to increase forecast skill through leveraging the strengths of each model forecast, we identified that this method did not considerably increase ACC skill when combining ECMWF and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S1).Fig. 2: Overall forecast performance of root zone soil moisture anomalies for different model runs in the contiguous United States.A Anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) and (B) Continuous Ranked Probability score (CRPS) for weekly leads 1–4 averaged over testing years 2018-2019 for different scenarios and dynamic models. Different lines represent different scenarios (described in Supplementary Table S1). In the legend, the number in parentheses is the total number of runs (either experimental runs or dynamic model reforecast runs) within each scenario. The lines displayed are averaged over both the contiguous United States and all model runs within each scenario; additionally, we have averaged over both ECMWF and GEFSv12 model runs (NWP). C Lead week 3 ACC of the combined DL and dynamic model (DL-DM) experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (EX29_G), a reanalysis-driven deep learning (DL) experiment (EX24), and the difference between them, with higher values indicating that EX29_G is more skillful than EX24. D Lead week 3 CRPS of EX29_G, EX24, and the difference between them, with lower values indicating that EX29_G is more skillful than EX24.Full size imageTo identify how input variables influence RZSM forecasts, we conducted a permutation feature importance test on each experimental run (see Methods). We found the most influential predictor for week 3 was GLEAM RZSM reanalysis input at weekly lag 1 (Fig. 3). The ACC values begin to decrease more rapidly after EXP25 (which contained no reanalysis atmospheric predictors). Subsequent experiments after EX25 in Fig. 3 included reanalysis atmospheric predictors and lower skill may be due to a combination of a.) diminished effects of previous atmospheric conditions at longer leads (low signal-to-noise ratio), b.) evolving land-surface conditions (precipitation and other hydrometeorological processes) during the three-week forecasts which are more impactful on RZSM variability or c.) inclusion of too many predictors which inhibits model learning through overfitting. Specifically, research has identified that increasing the number of inputs in a neural network can create a less robust model prone to overfitting and is unable to generalize to out-of-training samples37.Fig. 3: Permutation feature importance test with mean absolute error (MAE) and anomaly correlation (ACC) values averaged over the contiguous United States during the testing period 2018-2019 for forecast lead week 3.Each of the 29 experiments is labeled on the horizontal axis and is color-coded as purple for deep learning (DL) models, as blue for combined DL and dynamic models (DL-DM), and as green for bias-corrected DM models (DM-BC_DL). Average MAE across all RISE-UNet deep learning model experiments are presented in the color bar, with higher MAE values indicating that the input has a larger influence on the final prediction (see Methods for more information on permutation feature importance test). ACC of GEFSv12, ECMWF, and ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) are also provided. We selected the EMOS experiment with the highest skill out of our four tests. The red dots show the average ACC value for each experiment on the right vertical axis. Each input is labeled on the left-hand of the vertical axis, which is named as variable abbreviation_data source_lead or lag_the number of weeks (e.g., z200_obs_lag_Wk_1-3 is geopotential height from observations (reanalysis) over lag weeks 1–3) (see Supplementary Table S2 for more information on abbreviations). Inputs which have been averaged over multiple weeks are indicated by the number of weeks listed (e.g., z200_obs_lag_Wk_1-3 will have MAE values averaged over lag weeks 1–3).Full size imageSHAP values were computed for week lead 1 prediction to further estimate each input feature’s contribution to the final model prediction (see “Methods”). Using GEFSv12 as the forecast, it was observed that the most influential features impacting model outputs included GLEAM RZSM at week lag 1 as the most influential feature, followed by ERA5 tmax at week lag 1, GEFSv12 reforecast at week lead 1, GLEAM RZSM at week lag 2, and geopotential height (z200) from both ERA5 and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S2). The higher density of SHAP values for GLEAM RZSM week lag 1, which corresponds with negative SHAP values, indicates that wetter soil conditions will lead to a drying of soils in the predicted RZSM. While this may seem counterintuitive, it is probable that the model has learned that saturated conditions lead to future drying. GLEAM RZSM at week lag 1 also identifies that wetter soils can increase the predicted RZSM output, as seen with a slightly lower density of positive SHAP values. ERA5 tmax at week lag 1 identifies that lower temperature values lead to an increase in saturation in predicted RZSM. Z200 results from both ERA5 and GEFSv12 identify that below normal heights, associated with troughs, lead to an increase in RZSM predicted values (towards wetness) as observed with a slightly higher density of values with positive SHAP. These results were identified to be robust across five different random seeds, which details low variability between different SHAP runs (Supplementary Fig. S3).The best performing model runs included only inputs from observation RZSM and/or recursive RZSM predictions (Fig. 3). The highest skill model at week 3 (EXP29) contains inputs of only lagged RZSM reanalysis and recursive RZSM predictions. While this set of inputs is highly similar to EX18, the recursive RZSM predictions from weeks 1-2 within EX29 come from models which were trained on only week 1 lag of reanalysis atmospheric conditions and short-lead DM atmospheric forecasts (weeks 1-2); therefore, it is likely that this hybrid model EX29 retains the important atmospheric signals embedded within the recursive RZSM predictions in which it is trained (Supplementary Table S1). For clarity, EXP29 will be named as either DL-DM_G (trained on GEFSv12 reforecast and other data) or DL-DM_E (trained on ECMWF reforecast and other data). Hereafter, we refer ECMWF reforecast as ECMWF. It should be noted that predictions and subsequent verification metrics from DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E are highly similar; therefore, we only present one model within each figure.We evaluate the spatial distribution of skill between DL-DM_G, EMOS, and GEFSv12 (Fig. 4). For CONUS at week lead 3, a high ACC score is achieved with the DL-DM model in many regions (DL-DM_G; ACC >0.7), with both DL-DM_G being significantly better than GEFSv12 and EMOS in the Central, Northwest, and Southeast US. DL-DM models can attain ACC >0.6 over 58% of CONUS when compared to EMOS or GEFSv12, having only ~13%. The worse performing region(s) across all models are the Mississippi and Ohio Valley regions. An assessment of seasonal variability displays that months December-February (DJF) contribute most to the overall skill for week leads 3-4 (~0.80 ACC), followed by months June-August (JJA) with ACC between 0.60-0.65, September-November (SON) with ACC between 0.50-0.60, and the lowest average skill is in March-May (MAM) with ACC between 0.47–0.51 (Supplementary Fig. S4). The KGE metric demonstrates that both DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E are better calibrated when compared to raw reforecasts for each season with >70% of grid cells have a positive KGE value as compared ECMWF and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S5). ACC skill based on the most recent GLEAM RZSM input across CONUS displays that wetter conditions lead to a more skillful forecast at weekly leads 3-4 in the Western and Northern High Plains regions, while drier conditions lead to more skillful forecasts in the Northwest, Northeast, and Southeast (Supplementary Fig. S6).Fig. 4: Forecast skill of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomalies for lead week 3 in the contiguous United States.Left panel: Week 3 RZSM anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) for the testing period 2018-2019 in the contiguous United States. A, B Ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) and GEFSv12 are in the top row, (C, D) the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G, EX29_G) is in the middle row. E, F is the improvement in ACC for the DL_DM_G (EX29_G) relative to EMOS or GEFSv12. Right panel: Proportion of grid cells above ACC thresholds of 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9 for each model.Full size imageWe further investigate the model generalizability over the globe and re-train the models for China and Australia (Fig. 5). Again, we find that the highest skill is obtained with DL-DM_G spatial ACC improvements of 23% (18%) compared to the raw reforecasts for China (Australia) respectively for percentage of grid cells with ACC >0.6. For seasonal variability in China (Supplementary Fig. S7), the highest contribution to overall ACC skill for week leads 3-4 is from SON with average skill across leads (~0.62 ACC), proceeded by DJF (~0.54), MAM (~0.53), and JJA (~0.40). Improvements in skill relative to GEFSv12 display that the Tibetan plateau has no improvements in skill in JJA for weeks 3-4, while the eastern China agricultural region has improved skill during MAM and JJA. Seasonal skill improvements in Australia are primarily contributed from season JJA with averaged week lead 3-4 ACC of ~0.50, proceeded by MAM (~0.40), and similar results between DJF and SON (~0.37) (Supplemental Fig. S8).Fig. 5: Forecast skill of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomalies for lead week 3 in China and Australia.(Left panel) Week 3 RZSM Anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) for testing years 2018-2019 in (A, C, E) China and (B, D, F) Australia. GEFSv12 is in the top row, the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G, EX29_G) is in the middle row, and the bottom row is the difference in ACC between EX29_G and GEFSv12. (Right panel) Proportion of grid cells falling above ACC thresholds of 0.4,0.5,0.6,0.7,0.8,0.9 separated by forecast and region.Full size imageWe analyzed the continuous ranked probability score (CRPSS) to determine the extent to which the CRPS of RISE-UNet predictions were improved relative to raw forecasts (Supplementary Fig. S9). We identified that over CONUS, the CRPSS of DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E were improved over the entire region, with the Central, Northern High Plains, and Eastern coastal regions showing the highest improvements. In China, DL-DM models have CRPSS >0 in many regions except for the Central and Northwest, indicating that raw forecasts have a better CRPS in these regions. In Australia, DL-DM models also have CRPSS >0 in the Western and Eastern portions of the continent, but coastal regions indicate the CRPS of the raw dynamic forecasts is better relative to RISE-UNet.Predictability of dry extremesFor dry weekly RZSM anomalies below the 20th percentile, DL-DM_G is more skillful than raw reforecast based on true positive rate for weekly leads 4-5, false positive rate at leads 3 & 5, and Gilbert skill score at leads 3-4 (Supplementary Fig. S10). The DL-DM_G outperforms GEFSv12 and ECMWF forecasts in the Central and Western United States for the true positive rate, while ECMWF performed well in the Southeast United States, and GEFSv12 performed well only in a few areas in the West (Supplementary Fig. S11). While the models were trained using large samples from 2000–2015, it is worth noting that the sample size was small (n = 104) during the testing period (i.e., dry weekly RZSM anomalies below the 20th percentile from 2018-2019). A longer DM reforecast archive can improve the robustness of the evaluations. In addition, when comparing the difference between the predicted and observed (reanalysis) percentiles, DL-DM_G generally shows a smaller percentile difference in the Western United States, albeit a slight dry bias (Supplemental Fig. S12). ECMWF has a dry bias in the Southeast United States and a wet bias in certain locations in the Central and West, and GEFSv12 has both positive and negative percentile differences scattered in the South and West. Raw reforecasts of ECMWF and GEFSv12 and DL-DM_G predictions have a dry bias in the Northwest. Overall, the results indicate that the RISE-UNet generally outperforms dynamic model forecasts for extremes, while the false positives can predominate in certain regions. Over CONUS, we see that the Western United States has much higher true positive rates for anomalies under the 20th percentile, but the Southeast had low performance, which may be caused by shorter SMM in this region38.Flash drought case studiesFlash drought is a devastating natural hazard and results in a rapid change in water stress, and can directly impact RZSM. We investigate a series of flash drought case studies beginning with Eastern China, with a flash drought that intensified rapidly during August 2019 and was associated with a strong cyclonic anomaly over the western North Pacific and northeasterly wind anomalies over the northwestern side39,40. RZSM reanalysis data from GLEAM accurately captured a rapid drying of RZSM anomalies across Southeastern China (Fig. 6). DL-DM_G shows the lowest mean absolute error (MAE), highest spatial correlation (r), and highest structural similarity (SSIM) for all 100% of initializations when compared to GEFSv12. We also provide additional analysis of flash drought case studies over Australia and CONUS, which both occurred in 2019 (Figs. 7 and 8). Australia results indicate DL-DM_G improved 100% of forecasts for SSIM, r, and MAE when compared to GEFSv12. For the flash drought over the Southeast United States, DL-DM_G achieves the lowest MAE in 50% of initializations, the highest correlation (r) in 100%, and the highest SSIM in 67%. However, it still modestly underestimates the spatial extent and intensity of the drought, indicating room for further improvement in extreme event prediction.Fig. 6Week 3 root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomaly predictions for Eastern China in 2019, from left to right: GLEAM RZSM, the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G), and GEFSv12. Initialization dates are noted on the left of the figure, as well as the verification date of the reanalysis. The gold-colored box is the region of interest (showing severe flash drought), and the mean absolute error (MAE), structural similarity index (SSIM), and the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) evaluation metrics are provided in the text box for each image.Full size imageFig. 7Week 3 root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomaly predictions for Australia in 2019, from left to right: GLEAM RZSM, the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G), and GEFSv12. Initialization dates are noted on the left of the figure, as well as the verification date of the reanalysis. The gold-colored box is the region of interest (showing severe flash drought), and the mean absolute error (MAE), structural similarity index (SSIM), and the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) evaluation metrics are provided in the text box for each image.Full size imageFig. 8Week 3 root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomaly predictions for CONUS in 2019, from left to right: GLEAM RZSM, the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G), and GEFSv12. Initialization dates are noted on the left of the figure, as well as the verification date of the reanalysis. The gold-colored box is the region of interest (showing severe flash drought), and the mean absolute error (MAE), structural similarity index (SSIM), and the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) evaluation metrics are provided in the text box for each image.Full size imageDiscussionThis study demonstrates that combining RISE-UNet deep learning (DL) and dynamic models (DM) can provide skillful subseasonal RZSM and improve drought predictions. It improves the reanalysis-driven DL models, while considerably outperforming the state-of-the-art dynamic models GEFSv12 and ECMWF, and postprocessed bias-corrected dynamic models (DM-BC_DL, or EMOS). Through 29 model experimental runs, we find that the optimal model for lead weeks 1-2 takes antecedent RZSM and atmospheric reanalysis inputs combined with atmospheric reforecast inputs from dynamic models, while for weeks 3-4 it takes antecedent RZSM reanalysis and recursive RZSM predictions, which are embedded with information from atmospheric reanalysis and dynamic model forecasts from previous weeks. This finding suggests the importance of the first two-week dynamic model forecasts and antecedent soil moisture reanalysis for skillful subseasonal RZSM predictions, as also confirmed by the feature importance analysis based on permutation test and SHAP assessment (Fig. 3; Supplementary Fig. S2). Moreover, as great efforts have been made to develop skillful weather, water, and climate forecasts in operational centers around the world, our results show promise for developing efficient deep learning for skillful subseasonal predictions with relatively small computational resources. Since our hybrid model is concise, it can be efficiently trained and implemented in different regions over the globe for skillful, real-time subseasonal RZSM and drought predictions with up to 1000 realizations generated in < 60 s to robustly quantify epistemic uncertainty. Given the advances achieved by our model for significantly improved subseasonal RZSM forecast of dry extremes, it provides a promising tool that can be further implemented or explored for subseasonal predictions of other climate variables, such as extreme precipitation and temperature, moving beyond a 10-day weather forecast.We acknowledge that GLEAM may exhibit systematic biases relative to in-situ observations. Improving the quality of ground-truth reanalysis could therefore enhance future efforts to accurately predict rapid changes in RZSM and drought. Although we have not directly evaluated GLEAM soil moisture, previous research has conducted this evaluation with in-situ observations, finding a global average correlation of 0.6441. Research in the Tibetan plateau identified an R value of ~0.8 between in-situ measurements and GLEAM, which was higher than GLDAS42, and further evidence of a strong correlation between GLDAS and GLEAM has been identified regarding the direction of soil moisture trends43. An additional constraint is that, while SHAP values help attribute physical meaning to input features and quantify their influence on final RZSM or drought predictions across CONUS (Supplementary Fig. S2), they do not reveal how the model internally learns or integrates these features to generate forecasts. For example, although variables like tmax and z200 exhibit a stronger influence on predictions than others, it remains challenging to understand the underlying mechanisms the model uses to produce nationwide predictions. This limitation can be partially addressed by developing region-specific models that further incorporate physical understanding into data-driven approaches, enabling better interpretation of the underlying mechanisms.Our model is based on the RISE-UNet architecture, which is much concise compared to the current large AI models for global medium-range weather forecasts32,33,36,44. It used CRPSexp as a loss function for optimizing ensemble forecasts, which, to our knowledge, has not yet been incorporated in previous research, while showing superior performance compared to the widely used mean-squared error loss (MSE). For ensemble predictions, the CRPSexp is more intuitive than the MSE loss because of its ability to incorporate both the ensemble mean error as well as the standard deviation, which are integral for estimating forecast calibration. Despite the concise architecture, the RISE-UNet models have achieved significantly higher skill than the current state-of-the-art dynamic models in all the lead times, and skill improvement within the first two weeks is even more notable compared to the current large AI weather forecast models32,33. It is worth noting that the errors of the dynamic models were reduced substantially due to DL postprocessing. The reanalysis-driven DL or combined DL-DM models consistently show significantly higher performance than EMOS or raw dynamic models, suggesting the irreducible random errors from the DM at the subseasonal forecast range (i.e., beyond 2 weeks). Dynamic models GEFSv12 and ECMWF show limited ACC skill for predicting RZSM beyond 2 weeks when looking at regional averages (Fig. 2), but seasonal assessments identified spatiotemporal improvements in skill can be significant (Supplemental Figs. S4, S7, S8). We acknowledge that our sample size is small for the testing set years 2018-2019 (n = 104), and for seasonal evaluation, the sample size reduces to approximately n = 31, which can decrease the predictive potential of the model45. Our overall assessment of DL-DM seasonal skill improvements over raw and bias-corrected models displays which subregions have increased skill and elucidates forecast windows of opportunity which are unaccounted for in operational forecast systems and may assist in the mitigation of rapid-onset drought impacts.Our methodology incorporates the full reforecast ensemble spread rather than the ensemble mean, which increases the sample size by a factor of 11 and has a dual-fold benefit compared to traditional architectures. Including the full spread alleviates the need to train separate models specifically for standard deviation36,46 and can augment the training data size. By utilizing currently available ensemble reforecasts, which can have >100 real-time forecast members, computational burdens can be lightened and less effort invested in calibrating separate models for standard deviation. We find that the reanalysis-driven DL models that used antecedent RZSM always show much higher subseasonal forecast skill than dynamic models. This suggests that SMM plays an important role in subseasonal predictions, and SMM dynamics can be efficiently learned through DL, while not well captured by dynamic models. With additional inputs from lead weeks 1 and 2 of dynamic models, the skill for weeks 3 and 4 is further improved through iterative predictions taking previous lead times, which suggest combining DL and DM would be a promising avenue for developing skillful subseasonal forecasts. While DMs are physically constrained and error growth inhibits forecasts after two weeks, hybrid DL-DM models can identify positive signals where forecasts are correct and learn mapping functions to predict more skillfully. While our model has improved deterministic and probabilistic RZSM skill, physics-informed neural networks may be able to effectively capture and understand SMM dynamics and should be explored further within DL-DM forecasts47. Moreover, note that the predictability of weather and climate events are highly influenced by SMM19,48, therefore, improved subseasonal RZSM predictions may be useful for also improving predictions of other subseasonal phenomenon and deserves further studies.We observed that DL-DM predictions in some regions have low skill, such as in the Mississippi River, Ohio Valley, and Southwest regions within CONUS, which has been identified in previous post-processing research for temperature49. Horat and Lerch (2024) implemented a series of experiments with two different UNet architectures and found these same regions have low skill relative to climatology, regardless of the architecture. Here, we argue that for RISE-UNet, low RZSM autocorrelation can be a primary reason for both low skill within DMs as well as post-processed DMs (Supplementary Fig. S13). In the Mississippi, Ohio Valley, and Southwest regions, anomaly autocorrelation \(({\rho }_{k})\) for lags (k) greater than 21 days have noticeably smaller values, which indicate that previous anomalies are less likely to persist in the future, thus inhibiting predictability based solely on memory. While our research has combined both atmospheric and land surface conditions, which have been shown to increase forecast skill50, we find that combining these features did not adequately increase skill in these regions. A natural extension to this research would be the incorporation of additional predictors which influence precipitation and RZSM variability, including sea-surface temperature or high-frequency modes of variability (e.g., North Atlantic Oscillation, Madden Julian Oscillation)14,16,51. In addition, the global UNet models utilized by Horat and Lerch (2024) contained traditional skip connections between layers, which is different than our implementation of a regional RISE-UNet architecture, which concatenates intermediate predictions between layers. It is currently not known what differences in skill for post-processed reforecasts between a traditional UNet vs. RISE-UNet. We leave this to future research to comprehensively examine ensemble predictions trained with CRPSexp loss to identify if the decreased training cost associated with traditional UNet outweighs potential improvements over RISE-UNet.For CONUS, results of higher ACC, lower CRPS, and high CRPSS demonstrate that the RISE-UNet can increase both deterministic and probabilistic skill relative to raw and bias-corrected models (Fig. 2 and Supplemental Fig. S9). Across CONUS, averaged ACC values at lead times >3 weeks are higher than previous research which assessed multiple subseasonal-to-seasonal forecasts52 and ACC skill in week lead 3 in the Southeast is improved compared to13. RISE-UNet predictions show an increase in TPR for dry anomalies in the South, High Plains, and Western United States (Supplementary Figs. S11), which has been identified previously to be low within GEFSv1213. For lead times < 2 weeks, RISE-UNet has much improved deterministic skill across eastern China when compared to research models within the Subseasonal-to-Seasonal database53. Predictions are also improved for the western and southeastern Australia regions, as well as southeast and west China, when compared to the Norwegian Climate Prediction Model54, although a direct assessment is limited due to their research computing monthly average RZSM predictions. Within China, the CRPSS is greater than 0 across the majority of the land mass while in Australia, it is generally restricted to the Southeast coast and inland regions. For these regions with CRPSS < 0, it is notable that RZSM autocorrelation diminishes rapidly after 14 days (results not displayed). Based on spatial variations in seasonal skill13, which are also identified in our research, additional deep learning methods may need to account for different predictors being more impactful at different times of year. The RISE-UNet is trained on all available data, and the model has no explicit awareness of seasonality; therefore, to more effectively capture subregion variability, season-specific weighted predictors may assist in more effectively capturing dynamical relationships which influence RZSM variability.ECMWF and GEFSv12 subseasonal forecasts are not reliant on assimilated RZSM data during initialization, which allows them to work efficiently within an operational setting. This can be a disadvantage due to the importance of accurate land surface initializations, which are required for skillful forecasts of temperature and precipitation19. As future models are developed and data assimilation procedures implemented into land surface model initializations, we can expect that the quality of the dynamic model forecast will increase, and further post-processing using the RISE-UNet can subsequently correct model biases. Alternatively, future research can incorporate hydrological models which include a more extensive set of land surface parameterizations which account for land surface fluxes such as Noah-MP55,56. Additional constraints which may impact operational performance include using lagged RZSM from reanalysis which may not be directly available on a weekly basis due to data assimilation and quality control procedures. This can be circumvented by incorporating near real-time soil moisture data, such as from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Short-term Prediction and Transition Center.Finally, we should note several limitations of this study and potential future works. First, we chose GLEAM RZSM as our primary observational reference due to its moderate-to-high correlation with in-situ RZSM observations and eddy covariance towers across the globe41, but there are still discrepancies13. There is an imperative need to develop improved, accurate soil moisture estimations through improved land surface modeling and satellite remote sensing57. Second, our models did not account for large-scale teleconnections. While previous studies show that long-term predictability of soil moisture dynamics is mainly due to SMM, incorporating large-scale drivers could improve soil moisture predictability within the subseasonal timescale58. Moreover, with explainable DL, new sources of subseasonal predictability at the large scale could be potentially revealed. Third, SHAP values were constructed across CONUS, which limits a comprehensive understanding of how each feature influences the final prediction due to heterogeneity across the region. A more through investigation into smaller regions could more easily isolate the relative influence and interpretation of each feature. Lastly, despite the significant improvement achieved by our model compared to the current state-of-the-art dynamic models, the prediction of extreme events still needs further improvement. Since DL inherently suffers from extrapolation issues59, it will be a great challenge to predict unprecedented extreme events as future climate pattern shifts. Continuous efforts are needed to improve dynamic models’ parameterizations, resolutions, initializations, and physics, and further couple with a DL model to harness the strength of both modeling approaches.MethodsReanalysis dataWe obtained daily soil moisture from December 1999 - February 2020 for surface (0–10 cm) and rooting-zone (10–100 cm) and created a weighted average of surface and rooting-zone for 0–100 cm hereafter referred to as root-zone soil moisture (RZSM) from the Global Land Evapotranspiration Amsterdam Model (GLEAM v3.8a) data product. The weighted average was computed as the sum of each variable, which was multiplied by a scaling factor associated with depth with based on \({{RZSM}}_{{weighted}}=\tfrac{{surface}*10{cm}}{100{cm}}+\tfrac{{rooting}-{zone}*90{cm}}{100{cm}}\). GLEAM is a set of algorithms which estimates terrestrial evaporation, surface- and root-zone soil moisture, and hydraulic fluxes using satellite observations41,60. Soil moisture is modeled using both Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity and European Space Agency Climate Change Initiative satellites and assimilated with Noah Global Land Data Assimilation System reanalysis with data available globally at a spatial resolution of 0.25 x 0.25°. Data was bilinearly interpolated to a horizontal resolution of 0.5° and a seven-day rolling mean was applied to each grid cell. Seasonal anomalies for each day and grid cell were created by subtracting the seasonal mean computed between 2000–2015 from each observation date, excluding the validation or testing period. Seasons are defined according to conventional categories of DJF (December, January, February), MAM (March, April, May), JJA (June, July, August), SON (September, October, November). Seasonal distributions were created by grouping observations within the same calendar season. The seasonal mean was then subtracted to isolate anomalies.We retrieved hourly data for 2 m dewpoint temperature, 2 m maximum temperature (Tmax), 2 m minimum temperature (Tmin), precipitable water (pwat), surface pressure, and 200 hPa geopotential height (z200) from the fifth generation of European ReAnalysis (ERA5) between October 1999 - February 2020. ERA5 has been shown to be superior to Modern Era Retrospective Analysis version 2 over North America and Europe for convective processes, boundary layer height, temperature, and cloud cover61,62,63. We computed the difference between Tmax and Tmin, hereafter referred to as ∆tmp, and computed 2 m specific humidity (spfh) using dewpoint and surface pressure64. The rationale for including ∆tmp is that radiation resolving processes within models are less well resolved within low resolution models, which can be impacted by poor cloud representation, which impacts radiation feedbacks65. ∆tmp considers the diurnal temperature difference and a higher/lower temperature difference over land explicitly implies that there was either less/more cloud coverage that day or a frontal storm system occurred which can either increase or decrease ∆tmp. For volumetric soil water, the top 3 layers were weighted and summed by the same procedure as GLEAM RZSM. Within this study, we refer to the S2S ECMWF as ECMWF. The GEFSv12 model was initialized using GEFSv12-reanalysis, and the forecasts were generated by coupling the GFSv15.1 AGCM with Noah LSM to produce a global 11-member ensemble each Wednesday with a lead time of 35 days66. The first ensemble realization is the control forecast, while the remaining 10 realizations are stochastically perturbed. While the GEFSv12 reforecast data is available for 2020–2022 in a different repository, initializations during this period are produced with a different model version. For consistency, we did not incorporate that period into this study and only considered the period of 2000–2019. The first ten days of the GEFSv12-reforecast are provided on a spatial resolution of 0.25° and temporal steps of three hours, while the last twenty-five days are provided at a spatial resolution of 0.50° and temporal steps of six hours. We downloaded 1043 initializations between the years 2000–2019 for Tmax, Tmin, z200, spfh, and RZSM. For Tmax and Tmin, we retrieved only the maximum and minimum values for each day, respectively and computed ∆tmp. The first ensemble realization is the control forecast, while the remaining 10 realizations are stochastically perturbed. To align ECMWF and GEFSv12 reforecasts, we matched lead times based on valid forecast dates, rather than attempting to align initialization dates. For example, an ECMWF reforecast initialized on Monday, Dec 2, 2019 (and its 20-year hindcast ensemble) would be compared against a GEFSv12 reforecast initialized on Dec 2, 2019, even if ECMWF did not produce a forecast on every intervening day. We verified that this approach preserves forecast lead equivalency (e.g., week-3 lead = days 15–21), and we tested sensitivity to potential day-of-week effects, which showed negligible differences in skill scores across the majority of grid cells across CONUS. The process is straightforward and creates a new ECMWF file with a 43-day forecast with the first lead date matching the first lead date from GEFSv12. While short-lead forecasts are sensitive to initialization timing due to the strong influence of initial conditions, at longer leads (e.g., week-4), the marginal degradation in skill from a two-day difference in initialization date is negligible. Therefore, aligning forecast periods across GEFSv12 and ECMWF, even with minor mismatches in start dates, remains a reasonable approximation for comparative skill analysis. The verification and testing data were stacked similarly with sizes (1144 samples, 48 latitude grid cells, 96 longitude grid cells, N channels).Deep learning architecture and experiment setupModel architectureA climate variable at each time step can be viewed as a two-dimensional image. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are powerful for learning complex functional relationships across spatial dimensions and covariate features among different images. The UNet architecture based on CNN69 is a deep neural network model containing a symmetric encoding-decoding structure that learns both low- and high-level feature abstractions between covariates and across spatial regions. Previous studies have used UNet architectures to bias correct and post-process both short- and long-lead NWP ensemble forecasts of temperature, geopotential height, and precipitation, with results indicating better performance than raw forecasts for various leads and regions36,46,70. A new variant of the UNet is the UNet + +3, which contains a series of nested and dense skip connections connecting each encoder-decoder block with previous blocks across the same spatial dimensions [Fig. 1B]71. This nested architecture has benefits over traditional UNet, which can suffer from information loss as downsampling occurs and is overcome through multiple nested skip connections. We modified the original UNet + +3 architecture by adding inception, residual, and squeeze-and-excitation72 (SE) blocks to increase the model’s spatial relation understanding and feature space representation. The new model architecture is named as residual inception squeeze-and-excitation (RISE) UNet + +, hereafter referred to as RISE-UNet (Fig. 1). For each Inception operator block, we include four parallel convolutional filters using kernel sizes of 3 × 3, 5 × 5, 7 × 7, and max pooling layer 5 × 5 and filter sizes of [32,64,128,256] for the 1st through 4th encoder backbone respectively. After each convolution, batch normalization (BN) is applied, followed by the rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation, and we pass another 1 × 1 convolution kernel with the same number of previous filters, followed by BN. We concatenate the four parallel convolution blocks, add the original input as a residual connection to reduce diminishing gradients and finally apply a SE block with sigmoid activation function to the summed residual/inception block in order to weight inter-channel features. Dropout layers are applied within each convolutional block to act as a regularization technique to prevent overfitting and improve generalization. Between 10–25% of the two-dimensional layers are randomly dropped during the training process, which creates stochastic predictions during model inference over the testing period. We train the model individually (and recursively for selected experiments) for weekly leads 1–5. This set of functions allows the model to adjust model weights, which both decrease the error and increase the spread of the forecast, thereby retaining stochasticity similar to that of physically-based dynamic models.Weather and climate ensemble forecast systems employ various perturbation methods to account for uncertainty in initial conditions and allow for the quantification of uncertainties due to errors in initial conditions, model formulation, and physical parameterizations74,75,76,77. More specifically, when using a singular realization contrived from assimilated observations and processed through a physically-based land and atmospheric model, uncertainty can be imparted from instrument calibration error or model structural errors associated with parameterizations of complex processes. Small errors within initial conditions have been observed to rapidly amplify in weather forecasting and restrict the intrinsic predictability limit of forecast systems78; therefore, perturbation methods allow for inclusion of a wider range of plausible initial conditions to evaluate uncertainty in ensemble forecasts through sensitivity experiments and probabilistic evaluations. The RISE-UNet DL architecture accepts an ensemble of stochastically generated initial conditions and passes these inputs through a series of operators (convolution kernels, squeeze-and-excitation, and max-pooling), non-linear activation functions (ReLU and sigmoid), and dropout layers to produce stochastic ensemble forecasts for each lead week. For the DL and DL-DM scenarios, a forecast is made by recursively applying RISE-UNet to the previous prediction to produce a prediction at successive lead weeks 2–5 (N). For further clarification, weekly lag/lead inputs have been computed by the following pre-processing pipeline: apply a 7-day rolling mean, compute seasonal anomaly, and perform min-max standardization. For example, Week lag 1 of reanalysis represents the antecedent information from the day before the forecast initialization date through the previous week. Specifically, the scenario DM-BC_DL includes experiments EX0 and EX13, which bias-correct DM forecasts using reanalysis, where EX0 uses all previous reforecast weeks as input predictors, while EX13 only includes the current week (single predictor). The scenario DL includes only lagged reanalysis as inputs, with EX14-EX17 containing atmospheric variables and RZSM, while EX22-EX25 includes only RZSM. DL-DM is the combined model including both lagged reanalysis and DM reforecasts, which includes EX1-EX4, EX5-EX8, EX9-EX12, EX27-EX28, and EX29. EX1-EX4 includes atmosphere and RZSM from reanalysis, as well as recursively predicted RZSM inputs from the previous time step. Recursively predicted inputs are the predictions of the previous lead weeks from the DL-DM model, which are used to predict the next lead week. EX9-EX12 is identical to EX1-EX4 with the exception of including DM RZSM for week (N) as an input. EX5-EX8 includes only RZSM reanalysis and DM RZSM for week (N) as inputs, and EX18-EX21 further include recursively predicted RZSM. EX27-EX28 are identical to EX9-EX10, with the exception of including DM reforecast atmospheric inputs up to lead week two. The setup of experiments in this manner allows for a robust assessment of each set of inputs on forecast skill79.Feature importance evaluationPermutation testTo determine the impact of each input variable on model skill in the testing dataset (2018-2019), we conducted a permutation test on each input individually for each experimental run. The order of operations for the permutation test for each experimental run goes as follows: First, a single input variable was selected (e.g., RZSM observation week lag 1) and random Gaussian noise was added, with mean and standard deviation from training data input statistics. Second, the input data was transformed via min-max normalization based on the new minimum and maximum. Third, with only a single input transformed and all other inputs identical, the combined inputs were fed into the RISE-UNet pre-trained model, and 11 ensemble predictions were made for each initialization in the testing period. SHAP assigns each feature an importance value for a particular prediction by estimating the contribution of each feature to the model output. SHAP values are grounded in cooperative game theory and satisfy the property of additive feature attribution,$$f\left(x\right)=\,{{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{0}+\,\mathop{\sum }_{i=1}^{M}{{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}$$

To efficiently compute SHAP values, we used the Gradient Explainer, which estimates SHAP values based on the model’s gradients with respect to its inputs, integrated along a straight-line path from a baseline input to the actual input and computed as,$${{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\approx ({x}_{i}-{\acute{x}}_{i})\cdot {\int }_{\alpha=0}^{1}\frac{\partial f(\acute{x}+\alpha \left(x-\acute{x}\right))}{\partial {x}_{i}}d\alpha$$
